subject: Re: [junit] TDD compared to tradition development coupled with automated unit test generation
msgSnippet: ... Yes. They tend to generate tests I would never right, such as religiously checking what happens when I pass null for any method parameter in my entire
messageBody:
Danijel Arsenovski wrote:
> Hi,
>
>
>
> I had some difficulty in promoting TDD in my team (if you can call it
> so, too many short-term body-shopped personnel, with no TDD skills), so
> I started investigating some tools that permit generating unit tests "a
> posteriori".
>
> Would anyone like to share some experience with this type of tools,
> since they integrate better with traditional approach, contrary to
> "write test first".

Yes. They tend to generate tests I would never right, such as
religiously checking what happens when I pass null for any method
parameter in my entire system.

Also, they tend to constrain me to the idea that each method should have
separate tests, and that makes future refactorings more annoying: it
couples too many tests to the implementation details of a class.

Take care.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com
Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
